instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3299: What is 820-3299? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ONOF_L: What is SMC_ONOF_L? This is a typo of SMC_ONOFF_L When you see SMC_ONOF_L, assume they meant to type SMC_ONOFF_L.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi,
i have this imac with only one led1
i find some component broken like <RESISTOR>R5335</RESISTOR>, <CHIP>U5420</CHIP>, <CHIP>U9720</CHIP> (when i remove this last <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> in diode mode 0,020 became 0,250)
for the last i can't find the reference REF3333, is not the reference i think.
i would like to find in other board but when i search this ref, i find a lot of board but not this component.
Do you have an idea where can find it?
I think the SSD kill the board or the board kill the SSD, because he don't work.

i try without <CHIP>U9720</CHIP> but all no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>, is it normal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> pulses at least?
I saw <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> leakage issue sometime.

Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses when you trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
no pulse <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0_FET</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> when i push on the power button
I check the signal <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOF_L</SIGNAL> fall down when i push the button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Now check if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops at same tinme.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> must be high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> fall down when i push button.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_PCH_L</SIGNAL> stay always high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Then all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals should pulse at same time; if not is PCH issue.
However, check first if PCH gets all (other) signals required for power on sequence.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
ok i have no pulse on all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL>. i think it's power sequence problem.
I try to find it this day. i have a question for power supply, can i use a external power supply and apply 12V on the board? without the real supply because it's hard to check signal on the iMac.
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
finally i check power sequence like this example

G3H/RTC rails + 32kHz RTC clock → {SRTCRST, RTCRST, INTVRMEN, INTRUDER#, DSWVRMEN} → S5 rails → <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> → DPWROK → <SIGNAL>SLP_SUS</SIGNAL># → SUS rails → RSMRST# → BATLOW# → PWRBTN# → <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL># → <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL>#

Some signal are not present on this board. all seems good befor <SIGNAL>SLP_S5</SIGNAL> but no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> signal 
maybe a bad <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>? is it possible?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
We talk about Apple board, why do you write "#" here?

Trigger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
sorry i copy just a start sequence find on a website.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> fall when i short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, i tell you on previous message :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
If PCH gets all the signals required, then is bad; if yuo cannot get any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
I recommend you to use an o-scope; it can catch any fast peak pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
i use an tektronix tbs 1102B and i don't see anything on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.
Garbage or try to change <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> by donor?
thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3299</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Change PCH, if all RTC signals are good for sure...
